article.title: Star cluster disruption by a massive black hole binary

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the time evolution of projected stellar surface density for different simulation runs. What do the different colors represent?
choices: Different initial masses of the star cluster (SC).
Different orbital eccentricities of the SC.
Smoothed projected mass density of stars.
Different mass ratios between the two SMBHs.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3, what is the primary factor causing the difference in BHB shrinking between runs 1 and 2?
choices: Different initial masses of the SC.
The relative velocity between stars and the SMBHs.
The inclination of the SC orbit with respect to the BHB orbital plane.
The softening parameter used in the simulation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 displays the fraction of stars within the BHB loss cone. Why is this fraction initially much lower in run 3 compared to runs 1 and 2?
choices: Run 3 has a lower SC mass.
Run 3 uses a different softening parameter.
The SC in run 3 has non-zero orbital angular momentum.
The BHB in run 3 has a higher initial eccentricity.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 9 illustrates the final radial density distribution of stars. What is the approximate density profile (ρ) of the stellar distribution at large radii (r) in runs 1p and 2p?

Figure 12 shows the cumulative distribution of unbound stars based on their radial velocity. What is the primary reason for the significantly higher escape velocities observed in runs with the Dehnen potential (1p and 2p)?
choices: The presence of a Dehnen potential allows for multiple interactions between stars and the BHB.
The Dehnen potential increases the initial velocity dispersion of stars in the SC.
Runs with the Dehnen potential have a higher BHB mass ratio.
The Dehnen potential reduces the effect of dynamical friction.
